Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Elaborating Data Intensive Research Methods through Researcher-Practitioner Partnerships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data-driven decision making and the use of 'big data' in education are two practice and policy areas that have yet to be studied carefully at the level of teacher classroom instructional decision making. The researchers will partner with the Summit Public School, a charter management organization, to study the ways in which teachers use data from student virtual learning experiences to make decisions about instruction. The researchers will work with teachers, administrators and information technology support staff in four schools that employ an online learning platform that includes instructional resources and content assessments as a central structure in students' learning environments. Data intensive research methods will be used to mine the rich data arising from the students' use of the online resources and performances to determine the resources that a student needs next. The proposal seeks to determine the key challenges facing practitioners in their use of data intensive research methods and to identify what partnership activities best support evidence-based practices. The findings from this study will lead to an understanding of the utility and feasibility of a teacher's use of the volumes of data that come from virtual learning environments.

The researchers in this study will be working with the students, teachers and administrators from four schools, three high schools and one middle school using a design research perspective. Practitioners will determine particular problems of practice around which the identification and analysis of data will be focused. Students in mathematics courses will be provided access to digital resources that are aligned to content assessments. The researchers will examine the correlation of the use of selected resources and outcomes from those assessments as well as student surveys, and subsequent course taking patterns and successes. Hierarchical cluster analyses, binary factor analyses and hierarchical linear modeling techniques will be used to identify which resources are linked to increased likelihoods of student success. The analyses will be used to develop recommendations of particular resources teachers might make available to students and to develop an early warning system that will help teachers keep students on track.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to learn about the role that data from various technologies, such as digital learning environments and administrative data systems, could play in improving learning opportunities for students. These data are often framed in terms of “big data” in education. This project attempted to translate educational big data into a resource for improvement through a research-practice partnership between researchers at SRI International and Teachers College, Columbia University with practitioners from Summit Public Schools. Summit provides all learners with unique instructional experiences that are organized around project-based learning, personalized learning, and strong relationships between students and staff. Key to supporting a rigorous, college preparatory curriculum for every Summit student is a customized learning management system referred to as the Summit Learning Platform. Over the course of three years, researchers and practitioners collaborated to jointly develop research questions, analyze data from the Summit Learning Platform, and co-develop implications from multiple analyses.

In this project’s efforts to engage in collaborative, partnership-focused research, researchers used evidence-based practices and other successful partnerships to design various activities that supported researchers and practitioners engage in joint work. Thus, the partnership experimented with different approaches for supporting collaboration, and in testing out a given approach, the research team reflected on what worked and what didn’t and gathered multiple lessons learned. For example, the partnership developed a novel approach referred to as “data sprint” for collaboratively and rapidly developing data products and follow-on actions that could be taken up by practitioners. Feedback on this approach demonstrated that it was an effective and efficient way to bring researchers and practitioners together.

Across the many analyses and meetings, researchers identified the importance of a handful of supporting conditions and a general set of phases for engaging in what would later be referred to as collaborative data-intensive improvement (CDI). For example, we identified the importance of trusting relationships between researchers and practitioners; the use of an explicit improvement method; an intentional focus on creating learning events that benefit both researchers and practitioners; and a common workflow that facilitates data sharing, data analysis, and testing out potential changes to learning environments.

This project led to the development of a proof-case for how to use data-intensive research in support of school improvement efforts. Across nearly all partnership activities, the project strove to support both research and practice. To support research, the research team identified new ways of measuring important learning behaviors using data from digital learning environments as well as disseminated the various conditions and phases for engaging in CDI for the explicit purpose helping other research-practice partnerships better use data-intensive research techniques. In supporting practice, the research team helped Summit Public Schools answer multiple practitioner-focused research questions that led to more personalized learning experiences for more students.


Last Modified: 09/12/2017
Modified by: Andrew E Krumm
